p: The influenza C virus is predominantly found in humans, and infection in humans can cause respiratory and febrile symptoms that are similar to those caused by influenza A and B viruses. Influenza C virus infections are generally mild and self-limited but can also cause more severe lower respiratory tract illness, such as bronchitis and pneumonia [ 1, 2]. The infection is considered common based on high seroprevalence [ 3, 4, 5]. The influenza C virus has also been found in pigs, and there are some reports about interspecies transmission of the virus between humans and pigs [ 6, 7]. However, pigs are not considered to play a significant role in the transmission cycle of the viruses in humans [ 7, 8].
